response:
John Horton Conway was indeed an innovator in mathematics, and he did contribute to several areas of mathematical research, including his work on the Moonshine (or Monstrous Moonshine). However, it's important to note that the discovery of the connections between the Monster group and what are now called moonshine phenomena were actually made by Richard Borcherds. 

The Monster group, or M, is a sporadic simple group in mathematics, one of the five major families of finite simple groups. It has order 2^30 · 3^15 · 5^7 · 7^3 · 11 · 13 · 19 · 23 · 29 · 31 · 41 · 47 · 59 · 71, which is approximately \( 8 \times 10^{53} \). It's the largest of the 26 sporadic groups.

The Monster group was discovered by Bernd Fischer and Robert Griessner in the 1970s. It has a rich structure that includes various subgroups such as the Baby Monster, and it plays a significant role in algebra and combinatorics.

Richard Borcherds' work on moonshine phenomena connected the Monster group to modular functions and string theory. Specifically, he observed that there is a correspondence between representations of the Monster group (or certain "moonshine modules") and coefficients of what are now called mock modular forms, which were originally thought to be unrelated. The discovery of this connection led to significant advancements in the understanding of both monstrous moonshine and the structure of the Monster group.

This unexpected link between apparently very different areas of mathematics is one of the most intriguing aspects of the theory. Moonshine suggests a deep unifying structure that connects seemingly disparate objects, which has implications for many fields, including algebraic geometry, combinatorics, number theory, and string theory.
